translation.selectorsIntroductoryInformationP1: Selectors are templates that are used to bind style properties to elements in a document
translation.selectorsIntroductoryInformationP2: All selectors have their own weight. The greater the weight, the more important the selector. There is no point in cramming the weight of each selector. Just think about which selector has the smallest selection. The smaller the sample, the greater the weight
translation.typeSelectorsP1: Type selectors are the simplest selectors possible. Select all the elements on the page of a specific tag. Therefore they have very little weight
translation.typeSelectorsC:
Styles will be applied to all

on the page
translation.classSelectorsP1: Class selectors are more advanced selectors. Select all the elements on a page of a certain class. Have an average weight
translation.classSelectorsC: Styles will be applied to all elements with the title class on the page
translation.idSelectorsP1: The ID selector selects one element on the page by a unique id. Because of such a small sample, they have a huge weight that is very difficult to beat. Using ID selectors is considered bad practice today
translation.idSelectorsC: Styles will be applied to a single element with the button ID
translation.attributeSelectorsT: Selectors of the presence and value of the attribute
translation.attributeSelectorsP1: The attribute presence and value selectors select all elements by a specific attribute and its value. Very often they can be found when styling input
translation.attributeSelectorsC: Styles will be applied to all inputs on the page for which the type="radio" attribute is set
translation.universalSelectorP1: The universal selector adds styles to all elements on the page
translation.universalSelectorC: Styles will be applied to all elements on the page
translation.neighboringRelatedCombinatorP1: Looks like selector1 + selector2. Styles will be applied to all elements passing selector2 selection, before which there is an element passing selector1 selection in the DOM tree. It can often be found when styling lists
translation.neighboringRelatedCombinatorC: Styles will be applied to all <li> tags that have another tag before them
translation.childCombinatorP1: Looks like selector1 > selector2. Styles will be applied to all elements passing selector2 selection, which are direct descendants of elements passing selector1 selection. It occurs infrequently
translation.childCombinatorC:
Styles will be applied to all

tags that are children of the first level of elements with the container class
translation.commonRelatedCombinatorP1: Looks like selector1 ~ selector2. Styles will be applied to all elements passing selector2 selection, before which there is an element passing selector1 selection in the DOM tree. Both elements must belong to the same parent. This selector differs from the neighboring selector in that there may be other elements between selector1 and selector2. It occurs infrequently
translation.commonRelatedCombinatorC:
Styles will be applied to all

tags except the first, which are children of the first level of elements with the container class
translation.descendantCombinatorP1: Looks like selector1 selector2. Finds all the corresponding selector2 descendants of the element that fits selector1, and applies styles to them. Used everywhere
translation.descendantCombinatorC:
Styles will be applied to all

tags inside

tags
translation.pixelsP1: px is the most common unit of measurement that determines the size of elements on the screen. One pixel represents the smallest single point on the screen
translation.percentsP1: % - used to determine the size of elements relative to the size of the parent element or container
translation.emAndRemP1: em is a relative unit of measurement that depends on the font size of the parent element. The value of 1em is equal to the current font size. rem is similar to the EM unit of measurement, but the value of 1 rem is always equal to the font size of the root element (usually <html>)
translation.viewportP1: vw and vh are relative units of measurement, which are determined relative to the size of the visible area (viewport) of the browser. 1vw is equal to 1% of the width of the visible area, and 1vh is equal to 1% of the height of the visible area
translation.pseudoClassesIntroductoryInformationP1: A pseudoâ€”class in CSS is a keyword added to a selector that defines its special state
translation.hoverP1: :hover is applied to an element when the mouse cursor hovers over it
translation.hoverC: Styles will be applied to the <button> when the mouse hovers over it
translation.activeP1: :active is applied to the element while clicking on it
translation.activeC: Styles will be applied to the <button> when you click on it
translation.focusP1: :focus is applied to the element that is in focus (for example, when clicking on a text field)
translation.focusC: Styles will be applied to the <button> in focus (for example, selecting a button via Tab)
translation.visitedC: Styles will be applied to all visited links
translation.pseudoElementsIntroductoryInformationP1: A pseudo-element in CSS is a keyword added to a selector that allows you to style a certain part of the selected element
translation.beforeP1: ::before adds content before the content of the selected element. Works in conjunction with the content property
translation.beforeC: A dollar sign will be displayed before the list items
translation.afterP1: ::after adds content after the content of the selected item. Works in conjunction with the content property
translation.afterC: The ampersand sign will be displayed after the list items
translation.placeholderP1: ::placeholder is applied to a placeholder inside a text field or a text field with a mask
translation.placeholderC: Styles will be applied to the placeholder of all <input> c type="text"
translation.calcP1: calc() allows you to add the simplest mathematics to the site. We can add(+), subtract(-), multiply(*) and divide(/) different units of measurement. In all other mathematical functions we can also use these operators
translation.minAndMaxP1: min(a, b) and max(a, b) selects the minimum and maximum of the two values, respectively. They are important knowledge in adaptive layout
translation.clampP1: clamp(a, b, c) can be represented as a desired value bounded by a minimum and maximum value. It is also an extremely necessary thing when building an adaptive
translation.maxHeightMinHeightAndMaxWidthMinWidthP1: Logically, the values of the maximum /minimum height / width
translation.fontFamilyP1: font-family sets the font of the text. It is possible to specify several values, fonts at the beginning have a higher priority. There are also standard serif and sans-serif values, which are guaranteed to be available on all devices.
translation.fontWeightP1: font-weight determines the font thickness. You can specify the value with the words normal, bold, etc. But I prefer to use numeric values: 100, 200, 300...900. From 100 to 900 in increments of a hundred. You do not need to specify the units of measurement. It should also be noted that not all fonts have typefaces of all types
translation.textAlignP1: text-align is the alignment of the text along one of the edges. For a happy life, it is enough to know left, right, center and justify
translation.textShadowP1: text-shadow adds a shadow to the text. The color and three numeric values are specified in order: X-shift, Y-shift, and the degree of blur
translation.textDecorationP1: text-decoration underlines(underline), crosses out(line-through) or crosses out (overline) text
translation.colorIndicationFormatsP1: Named colors are predefined color names such as "red", "blue", "green", etc.
translation.colorIndicationFormatsP2: HEX codes are a hexadecimal representation of a color consisting of the characters 0-9 and A-F. For example, "#FF0000" represents red
translation.colorIndicationFormatsP3: RGB is a representation of a color as a combination of the values of the red (R), green (G) and blue (B) components. For example, "rgb(255, 0, 0)" represents red.
translation.colorIndicationFormatsP4: RGBA - similar to RGB, but with the addition of an alpha channel that determines the transparency of the color. For example, "rgba(255, 0, 0, 0.5)" represents a translucent red color.
translation.colorIndicationFormatsP5: CSS3 color functions - CSS3 provides functions for creating colors, such as linear-gradient() and radial-gradient(). These functions allow you to create gradients and other complex color effects.
translation.colorP1: color sets the color for the text
translation.backgroundColorP1: background-color sets the color for the element's background
translation.backgroundImageP1: background-image sets the background image for the element via url("URL")
translation.backgroundAttachmentP1: background-attachment sets whether the background image will scroll along with the content of the element
translation.backgroundRepeatP1: background-repeat sets the way the background repeats. The main values are repeat, round and no-repeat
translation.backgroundSizeP1: background-size sets the size of the background. The main values are: contain, cover and an arbitrary value
translation.backgroundPositionP1: background-position sets the position of the background. The values can be specified in words, or they can be arbitrary
translation.displayFlexP1: display: flex allows you to make elements in the block streamlined, and also gives access to other flex properties. For comparison, the standard value is block
translation.flexDirectionP1: Using flex-direction, we can specify the direction of stacking elements
translation.flexWrapP1: flex-wrap is responsible for transferring elements
translation.justifyContentP1: justify-content is responsible for placing elements in the block. The most commonly used values are center, space-between and space-around
translation.displayGridT1: display: grid, grid-template-columns, grid-template-rows and unit of measurement fr
translation.displayGridP1: display: grid behaves like display: block, but opens access to interesting CSS properties that allow you to create a grid on the page, as well as to the unit of measurement fr. fr can be conditionally called a "part". The record repeat(3, 1fr) means "divide the block into 3 equal parts". repeat(5, 1fr) respectively "divide the block into 5 equal parts". 30% 60% 1fr knows that all available space is divided into 3 unequal parts. One part takes 30%, the second part 60%, and the third is what remains. In this example, it is 10%.
translation.displayGridP2: grid-template-columns and grid-template-rows respectively mean division into columns and rows. It turns out something like a table
translation.gridAreasP1: grid-template-areas is a common property for columns and rows. It has a specific syntax, but allows you to set a non-standard grid. Grid-area is used for marking grid elements
translation.gapP1: gap is the gaps between the grid elements, but they do not always work the way we want
translation.displayNoneP1: display: none completely removes the block from the page as if it does not exist
translation.displayNoneC: Pressing the button adds and removes display: none
translation.displayBlockP1: display: block is the default display value. Nothing interesting
translation.positionP1: position sets the way the element is positioned relative to the browser window or other objects on the web page. The default value is static. The most common values are absolute, relative and fixed. All of them open new properties left, top, right and bottom. This is a kind of indentation from a certain side. The value of position depends on what the margins will be relative to
translation.positionAbsoluteP1: absolute - margins relative to the origin on the page (upper-left corner), but if you put such an element inside the relative element, the positioning will occur relative to the parent element. In addition, the element with position: absolute becomes incorporeal and intangible
translation.positionRelativeP1: relative - margins relative to itself. The element does not become disembodied, but its body does not move
translation.positionFixedP1: fixed - similar to absolute, but anchored to a specific position on the screen
translation.transformP1: transform is an extensive CSS property that includes a lot of values that allow you to move the element, rotate, scale, and so on. But there are only a few common ones: translate(x, y), rotate(deg) and scale(x, y). There are also derivatives of them: translateX(x), translateY(y), scaleX(x), and so on. The remaining values are almost not used
translation.transformTranslateP1: transform:translate() is essentially very similar to position: relative. It also allows us to shift elements relative to ourselves
translation.transformRotateP1: transform:rotate() allows us to rotate elements on the page
translation.transformScaleP1: transform: scale() changes the size of the element along the axes
translation.transitionP1: transition allows you to add a smooth change to the CSS property. The required property is specified (you can specify all), as well as the time in milliseconds or seconds. You can specify the delay before the animation starts and the animation curve
translation.keyframesAndAnimationP1: @keyframes allows us to create an animation using keyframes and give it a name. Keyframes are set as percentages of the animation. With animation, we apply the created animation and specify additional parameters, such as time, delay, animation curve, repeatability, etc.
translation.keyframesAndAnimationP2: For the sake of interest, the gradient is implemented like this:
translation.borderP1: border adds a tangible frame to the element that is part of it. The thickness of the frame, color and style of the frame are specified. In 90% of cases, a solid solid frame is sufficient
translation.outlineP1: outline adds an intangible frame to an element that is not part of it. The thickness of the frame, color and style of the frame are specified. In 90% of cases, a solid solid frame is sufficient
translation.borderRadiusP1: border-radius rounds the edges of the element
translation.paddingP1: padding adds internal padding to an element
translation.marginP1: margin adds external margins for the element
translation.marginP2: The auto value can be used as a centering method
translation.zIndexP1: z-index is an analogue of layers in Photoshop. The higher the value, the higher the layer
translation.boxShadowP1: box-shadow is a copy of text-shadow, but for block elements
translation.alignItemsP1: align-items aligns the items in the block. Usually only center is used
translation.cursorP1: cursor indicates the type of mouse pointer when hovering
translation.visibilityP1: visibility: hidden hides an element on the page, but the space occupied by it remains occupied. It is possible to animate
translation.listStyle: list-style adjusts the style of the list pointers. You can choose from a variety of existing ones, or you can specify yourself
